Looking to travel in the footsteps of royalty? You don't have to go far to experience some blue-blooded delights. Fans of the royal family around the world are celebrating Queen Elizabeth II becoming the longest reigning UK monarch. But flag-waving royalists closer to home don't need to travel all the way to merry old England to get their fix. In fact, there are 26 monarchies around the world, ruling over 43 countries.Online accommodation site Booking.com has released its list of five countries that have ruling monarchs, and make fabulous holiday destinations too. JAPAN: The Japanese Yamato dynasty is the world's oldest, tracing its origins back to 660. Emperor Akihito has reigned since 1989 and lives at the Imperial Palace in Kyoto. Travellers wanting to enjoy a unique taste of Japanese royalty can pay a visit to the Imperial Palace with its vast, perfectly manicured grounds and intricate architecture. READ MORE: Japan creates google 'cat view' to lure travellers While the stunning Japanese gardens are open all year round, the inner grounds of the palace are only open to the public on two specific days per year. The best time to catch a glimpse of the Imperial Family is on January 2, during the annual New Year's greeting, and on December 23, the Emperor's Birthday. THAILAND: 
The Monarchy is still very much revered and respected in Thailand, and despite a number of recent health scares, King Bhumibol Adulyadej is currently the world's longest serving monarch, reigning for 69 years. 
Photos of the King are displayed everywhere in Thailand and the national anthem is played in public spaces everyday at 8am and 6pm. Booking.com 
The official residence of the King is the Zarzuela Palace, just outside of Madrid, but those wanting to explore the history of Spanish royalty can pay a visit to The Royal Palace. 
READ MORE: Expat tales: An Aucklander in Thailand 
The Grand Palace of King Bhumibol Adulyadej is located in Bangkok, and has been hailed as one of the "must-see" sights and "spiritual hearts" of the Thai Kingdom. 
Built in 1782, the palace has been called home by various Thai Kings for over 150 years, and is famed for its beautiful towering statues. 
But be warned, a strict dress code applies when trying to enter the Grand Palace and nearby Temple of the Emerald Buddha. 
SPAIN: 
Forty-seven-year-old King Felipe VI has ruled Spain for little more than a year following the abdication of his popular father King Juan Carlos I. 
The official residence of the King is the Zarzuela Palace, just outside of Madrid, but those wanting to explore the history of Spanish royalty can pay a visit to The Royal Palace (Palacio Real) which is used for state ceremonies and official banquets and has several rooms and gardens open for the public to explore 
READ MORE: Spain named world's best country for tourists 
Rebuilt after the original Alcázar was destroyed by a fire on Christmas Eve in 1734, the Royal Palace is filled with important works of art and the Royal Armoury. 
With pieces hailing from the 15th century onwards, the collection, together with the imperial of Vienna, is though to be one of the best in the world. 
The Spanish love their royal family, and they can often be seen gracing the cover of popular magazine, HELLO! 
MOROCCO: 
King Mohammed VI has ruled Morocco since 1999 and voluntarily reduced his powers following the Arab Spring of 2011. 
Dar al-Makhzen is the official royal residence and is located in the walled capital of Rabat. Rabat was designed as an Imperial City in the 18th century by the Alaouite sultan Muhammad ibn Abdallah. It is the seventh largest city in Morocco and has been recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage site. 
Lonely Planet describes the entrance to Dar el-Makhzen as a "stunning example of modern restoration." The 80 hectares of grounds which surround the palace are not open to the public, but visitors to Morocco, wanting to experience the rich royal history of the country, should pay visit to the Museum of Moroccan Arts in Tangiers. 
The museum is housed in another equally important and beautiful historic site, built for the reign of the sultan Moulay Ismali in the 17th century. The Museum displays works of art from across Morocco, and also includes historic artefacts like firearms, finds from Roman sites and a life-size Carthaginian tomb.

TONGA: 
His reign may have started in 2012 but King Tupou VI of Tonga was only coronated in July, 2015. The new king became the 24th Tu'i Kanokupolu, an ancient Tongan title that pre-dates the monarchy, and his coronation celebrations lasted 11 days. 
Almost modest by royal standards, the official residence of the King is located on the beach front and made of wood. 
The palace may be off limits but it can be viewed from and waterfront, and the island paradise of is well worth the visit.
